awd_titl_txt: G8 Initiative: REO Kiln - Reduced Emission Cement: Cradle to Grave Material Applications and Accounting
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF award funds U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by the G8 Research Councils Initiative "Interdisciplinary Program on Material Efficiency - A first step towards sustainable manufacturing". This is a pilot collaboration among the U.S. National Science Foundation, the Canadian National Sciences and Engineering Research Council (NSERC), the French Agence Nationale de la Recherche (ANR), the German Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG), the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS), the Russian Foundation for Basic Research (RFBR),and the United Kingdom Research Councils (RCUK), supporting collaborative research projects selected on a competitive basis that are comprised of researchers from at least three of the partner countries. 

This award funds research supporting the design of a redesigned cement plant with improved material efficiency,including reduced carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions and enhanced waste disposal. These objectives will be met by redesigning the manufacturing process, enhancing the re-use and recycling of waste concrete, and producing longer lasting products by enhancing the mineral properties of clinker. The redesign will replace air with oxygen in the combustion process. The required flue gas recycling facilitates the capture of carbon dioxide as well as the expansion of alternative fuels, in particular sulfur, which reacts with limestone to produce gypsum, a component of cement. Increasing the CO2 partial pressure within the kiln changes process conditions sufficiently to alter the reaction sequence. Recycling will also be investigated as a unit process that carbonates lime leached from waste concrete using atmospheric carbon dioxide. The resulting limestone can be re-used as kiln feed or as filler in the paper industry. Improved mineral quality is derived from the shorter, hotter flame possible with oxygen combustion, resulting in longer product life. While additional energy will be required to produce the oxygen, the optimization will reduce thermal load and carbon dioxide emissions. Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) will be used to quantify material and energy flows, which can then be compared to existing cement manufacturing processes. 

If successful, the novel cement manufacturing process will provide a net reduction in carbon dioxide emissions using an expanded alternative fuel portfolio that consumes its own waste, making a positive contribution to the upcoming challenges related to an aging infrastructure in OECD countries, and growing infrastructure in non-OECD countries. Sustainable development is critical as it is the only ethical means to reduce poverty, raise living standards and mitigate the impacts of development.

por.por_cntn:
Growing concerns about climate change has led to significant efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. While significant work has be done to identify strategies to reudce emissions from the energy sector, there is still a need to evalate mitigation strategies from other sectors. Cement manufacturing accounts for approximately 5% - 7% of the global CO2 emissions. 58% of CO2 emissions in the cement manufacturing process are the result of calcination and the remaining result from energy sources (fuel combustion and electricity production) and materials. A promising process that could reduce CO2 emissions from cement manufacturing relies on a Reduced Emission Oxygen (REO) Kiln. 

The REO-Kiln process represents a redesign of the cement manufacturing process, enhancing the re-use and recycling of waste concrete, and producing longer lasting products by enhancing the mineral properties of clinker. The redesign will replace air with produced oxygen within the combustion process. The required flue gas recycling facilitates the capture of CO2 as well as the expansion of alternative fuels, in particular sulfur, which reacts with limestone to produce gypsum, a component of cement. Increasing the CO2 partial pressure within the kiln changes process conditions sufficiently to alter the reaction sequence. While additional energy will be required to produce the oxygen, the optimization will reduce thermal load and CO2 emissions.

Life cycle assessment (LCA) is a methodological framework that allows for the evaluation of the environmental impacts of a product or process throughout its life cycle. It thus includes inputs, output, and associated impacts of raw material extraction, production and processing, transportation, use, and end-of-life. For this project we developed a LCA model to evaluate the life cycle CO2 emissions associated with cement produced via the REO-Kiln process, which we compared to the life cycle CO2 emissions of conventional cement. The model relies on data from modeling and experimental efforts at partner institutions (including the Royal Military Academy in Canada, and Imperial College, London). Furthermore, to account for uncertainty in model inputs, we relied on a Monte Carlo simulation framework to produce probabilistic result of the life cycle CO2 emissions from REO-Kiln cement. 

The results of this project suggest that the REO-Kiln process can reduce the life cycle CO2 emissions of cement only if carbon capture and sequestration (CCS) is available at the plant. Conventional cement has life cycle CO2 emissions ranging between 890 and 1,050 kg CO2 per ton of cement, while REO-Kiln cement produced in a plant with CCS has life cycle CO2 emissions ranging between 265 and 350 kg CO2 per ton of cement. If CCS is not available, then the life cycle CO2 emissions of REO-Kiln cement would range between 940 and 1,110 kg CO2 per ton of cement, which could result in an increase in CO2 emissions from global cement production.
